events.title: Discovery of X-rays by Wilhelm Röntgen
events.description: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen announced the discovery of a new kind of radiation, which he called X-rays, a fundamental breakthrough in physics and medicine.
events.significance: This discovery revolutionized medical diagnostics and earned Röntgen the first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901.

events.title: Kaiser Wilhelm II Abdicates, German Empire Ends
events.description: Kaiser Wilhelm II abdicated the throne, leading to the proclamation of the Weimar Republic and the end of the German monarchy following Germany's defeat in World War I.
events.significance: Marked the end of imperial Germany and set the stage for the Weimar Republic amidst post-war turmoil.

events.title: Kristallnacht: The Night of Broken Glass
events.description: In coordinated attacks against Jews throughout Nazi Germany and Austria, synagogues were burned, Jewish businesses vandalized, and thousands of Jews arrested.
events.significance: This violent pogrom signaled a brutal escalation in the Nazi regime's persecution of Jews, leading eventually to the Holocaust.

events.title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
events.description: Massive citizen-led demonstrations and political changes led to the opening of the Berlin Wall, which had separated East and West Berlin since 1961.
events.significance: Symbolized the end of the Cold War division in Europe and paved the way for German reunification.

events.title: Democracy in South Africa Solidifies with Multi-Racial Elections
events.description: South Africa held its first multi-racial general elections, marking an official end to apartheid and electing Nelson Mandela as the first Black president.
events.significance: Signified a historic transition to democratic governance and the dismantling of institutional racial segregation.
